sn22.90:4.1: At one time several senior mendicants were staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana.
sn22.90:4.2: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Channa came out of solitude. Taking a key, he went from dwelling to dwelling, going up to the senior mendicants and saying:
sn22.90:4.3: “May the venerable senior mendicants advise me and instruct me! May they give me a Dharma talk so that I can see the teaching!”
sn22.90:5.1: When he said this, the senior mendicants said to Venerable Channa:
sn22.90:6.12: And yet my mind isn’t eager, confident, steady, and decided about the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.
sn22.90:6.14: And the mind reverts to thinking:
sn22.90:6.16: But that doesn’t happen for someone who sees the teaching.
sn22.90:6.17: Who can teach me the Dharma so that I can see the teaching?”
sn22.90:7.2: “The Venerable Ānanda is staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery. He’s praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions. He’s quite capable of teaching me the Dharma so that I can see the teaching.
sn22.90:7.3: Since I have so much trust in Venerable Ānanda,
sn22.90:7.4: why don’t I go to see him?”
sn22.90:7.5: Then Channa set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robes, set out for Kosambi. He went to see Ānanda in Ghosita’s Monastery,
sn22.90:7.7: and told him what had happened. Then he said:
sn22.90:10.5: “May Venerable Ānanda advise me and instruct me! May he give me a Dharma talk so that I can see the teaching!”
sn22.90:11.1: “I’m pleased with Venerable Channa already. Hopefully you’ve opened yourself up and cut through your emotional barrenness.
sn22.90:11.3: You are capable of understanding the teaching.”
sn22.90:11.4: Then right away Channa was filled with lofty rapture and joy:
sn22.90:11.5: “It seems I’m capable of understanding the teaching!”
sn22.90:12.1: “Reverend Channa, I heard and learned directly from the Buddha his advice to the mendicant Kaccānagotta:
sn22.90:12.2: ‘Kaccāna, this world is for the most part dependent on the dual notions of existence and non-existence.
sn22.90:12.3: But when you truly see the origin of the world with right understanding, you won’t have the notion of non-existence regarding the world.
sn22.90:12.4: And when you truly see the cessation of the world with right understanding, you won’t have the notion of existence regarding the world.
sn22.90:12.5: The world is for the most part shackled to attraction, grasping, and insisting. But if—when it comes to this attraction, grasping, mental resolve, insistence, and tendency—you don’t get atracted, grasp, and commit to the notion “my self”,
sn22.90:12.6: you’ll have no doubt or uncertainty that what arises is just suffering arising, and what ceases is just suffering ceasing.
sn22.90:12.7: Your knowledge about this is independent of others.
sn22.90:12.8: This is how right view is defined.
sn22.90:12.10: “All doesn’t exist”: this is the second extreme.
sn22.90:12.11: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One teaches by the middle way:
sn22.90:12.12: Ignorance is a condition for choices.
sn22.90:12.13: Choices are a condition for consciousness. …
sn22.90:12.14: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
sn22.90:12.15: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.  …
sn22.90:12.16: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’”
sn22.90:13.1: “Reverend Ānanda, this is how it is when you have such venerables as spiritual companions to advise and instruct you out of kindness and compassion.
sn22.90:13.2: And now that I’ve heard this teaching from Venerable Ānanda, I’ve comprehended the teaching.”
